Or the original "Mechanical Turk" https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mechanical_Turk where Amazon got the name for https://www.mturk.com/ from?

There's three troubles (at least) I see with ChatGPT:
* The issue with seemingly exploiting people doing the hard work of filtering out inappropriate content.
* The issue with using content they may not have permission to use (and then passing the buck to the user in order to verify if they have permission to use the outputs, while providing no help for that process) https://write.as/o1u8x2uycky1m
* Despite having a large amount of information, the output is not always correct - and I get that they say that on the start page, but it needs to be highlighted a lot more as people seem to think it is something it isn't https://blog.edross.co.uk/post/706555817427632129/you-must-not-trust-chatgpt

I've enjoyed using it (mostly for fiction, where there is more room for veering away from truth) https://blog.edross.co.uk/archive/tagged/chatgpt
But I have been wondering, especially after the Kenya revelations, if it is worth it.

Yes, sometimes drugs are vital. But the message is: Buyer beware, buyer first try physical activity, mindfulness, sleep, diet, etc.

python -m pip install --upgrade pandas==1.5.3

title: The Lisa: Apple's Most Influential Failure - CHM

last_post.content:
The Computer History Museum in Mountain View has worked with Apple to secure the release of the source code for the OS and office applications of the #AppleLisa computer.

Arguably, this is the earliest comprehensive #GUI environment for a personal computer, and it was first for sale 40 years ago today. It was written in a whole lot of #Pascal .

You can download it here:

https://computerhistory.org/blog/the-lisa-apples-most-influential-failure/

Meanwhile, on LisaList2, folks are starting to dig in:

title: Information Controls Fellowship Program 2023 - The Citizen Lab

last_post.content:
Come work with us @citizenlab

The Information Controls Fellowship Program (ICFP) from the Open Technology Fund (OTF) fosters research, outputs, and creative collaboration on repressive Internet censorship and surveillance issues. The program supports examination into how governments in countries, regions, or areas of OTF’s core focus are restricting the free flow of information, cutting access to the open Internet, and implementing censorship mechanisms, threatening global citizens’ ability to exercise basic human rights and democracy; work focused on mitigating such threats is also encouraged.
